p: More generally, causal networks are a way of combining expert knowledge with probability [ 47]. The factorization (5.1) allows for the ready incorporation of knowledge within a local semantics, and yields results that are comprehensible to humans [ 53]. In the published Discussion of Lauritzen & Spiegelhalter [ 47, p. 210], Pearl invokes the following statement (attributed to G. Halter): ‘Probability is not really about numbers; it is about the structure of reasoning’. Making the subjective assumptions explicit leads to transparency in the subsequent analysis [ 54] and provides an audit trail for decision-makers [ 55]. This is important since, as Beven [ 55, p. 1661] puts it, ‘Decision and policy makers are … far more interested in evidence than uncertainty’.
